content: Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

Acquire and use accurately a range of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Language

content: Acquire and use accurately a range of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when encountering an unknown term important to comprehension or expression.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Language

content: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Language

content: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases by using context clues, analyzing meaningful word parts, and consulting general and specialized reference materials, as appropriate.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Language

content: Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Language

content: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Language

content: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Language

content: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate.
Integrate multimedia and visual displays into presentations to clarify information, strengthen claims and evidence, and add interest.

Present claims and findings (e.g., argument, narrative, response to literature presentations), emphasizing salient points in a focused, coherent manner with relevant evidence, sound valid reasoning, and well-chosen details; use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.
Delineate a speaker's argument and specific claims, evaluating the soundness of the reasoning and relevance and sufficiency of the evidence and identifying when irrelevant evidence is introduced.

Analyze the purpose of information presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) and evaluate the motives (e.g., social, commercial, political) behind its presentation.

Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 8 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly.
Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and communicative tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Speaking and Listening

content: Make strategic use of digital media and visual displays of data to express information and enhance understanding of presentations.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Speaking and Listening

content: Present information, findings, and supporting evidence such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning and the organization, development, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Speaking and Listening

content: Evaluate a speaker's point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Speaking and Listening

content: Integrate and evaluate information presented in diverse media and formats, including visually, quantitatively, and orally.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Speaking and Listening

content: Prepare for and participate effectively in a range of conversations and collaborations with diverse partners, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Speaking and Listening

content: Write routinely over extended time frames (time for reflection and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.
meta: Writing Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

Writing Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, using search terms effectively; assess the credibility and accuracy of each source; and quote or paraphrase the data and conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.
meta: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Writing Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Conduct short research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question), drawing on several sources and generating additional related, focused questions that allow for multiple avenues of exploration.
meta: Research to Build and Present Knowledge
Writing Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on how well purpose and audience have been addressed.
meta: Writing Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and present the relationships between information and ideas clearly and efficiently.
meta: Writing Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies, Science, and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

content: Write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events, scientific procedures/ experiments, or technical processes.

content: Write arguments focused on discipline-specific content.

content: Conduct short research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question), drawing on several sources and generating additional related, focused questions that allow for multiple avenues of exploration.

content: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and present the relationships between information and ideas efficiently as well as to interact and collaborate with others.

With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on how well purpose and audience have been addressed.
Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

content: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, assess the credibility and accuracy of each source, and integrate the information while avoiding plagiarism.

College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Writing

content: Conduct short as well as more sustained research projects based on focused questions, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation.

College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Writing

content: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce and publish writing and to interact and collaborate with others.

content: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach.

content: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.

content: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event sequences.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Writing

content: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Writing

content: Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Writing

content: By the end of grade 8, read and comprehend science/technical texts in the grades 6—8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.
meta: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity
Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Compare and contrast the information gained from experiments, simulations, video, or multimedia sources with that gained from reading a text on the same topic.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Distinguish among facts, reasoned judgment based on research findings, and speculation in a text.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Integrate quantitative or technical information expressed in words in a text with a version of that information expressed visually (e.g., in a flowchart, diagram, model, graph, or table).
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Analyze the author's purpose in providing an explanation, describing a procedure, or discussing an experiment in a text.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to an understanding of the topic.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Determine the meaning of symbols, key terms, and other domain-specific words and phrases as they are used in a specific scientific or technical context relevant to grades 6—8 texts and topics.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Follow precisely a multistep procedure when carrying out experiments, taking measurements, or performing technical tasks.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Determine the central ideas or conclusions of a text; provide an accurate summary of the text distinct from prior knowledge or opinions.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of science and technical texts.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in Science and Technical Subjects 6—12

content: By the end of grade 8, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 6—8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.
meta: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity
Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: Analyze the relationship between a primary and secondary source on the same topic.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: Distinguish among fact, opinion, and reasoned judgment in a text.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: Integrate visual information (e.g., in charts, graphs, photographs, videos, or maps) with other information in print and digital texts.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: Identify aspects of a text that reveal an author's point of view or purpose (e.g., loaded language, inclusion or avoidance of particular facts).
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: Describe how a text presents information (e.g., sequentially, comparatively, causally).
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including vocabulary specific to domains related to history/social studies.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: Identify key steps in a text's description of a process related to history/social studies (e.g., how a bill becomes law, how interest rates are raised or lowered).
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: Determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary of the source distinct from prior knowledge or opinions.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources.
meta: Reading Standards for Literacy in History/Social Studies 6—12

content: By the end of the year, read and comprehend literary nonfiction at the high end of the grades 6—8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.
meta: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

content: Analyze a case in which two or more texts provide conflicting information on the same topic and identify where the texts disagree on matters of fact or interpretation.

Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different mediums (e.g., print or digital text, video, multimedia) to present a particular topic or idea.
Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints.
Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.

Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts. (See grade 8 Language standards 4–6 for additional expectations.)
Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
By the end of the year, read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems, at the high end of grades 6—8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.
meta: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

content: Analyze how a modern work of fiction draws on themes, patterns of events, or character types from myths, traditional stories, or religious works such as the Bible, including describing how the material is rendered new.
Analyze the extent to which a filmed or live production of a story or drama stays faithful to or departs from the text or script, evaluating the choices made by the director or actors.
Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Compare and contrast the structure of two or more texts and analyze how the differing structure of each text contributes to its meaning and style.

Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts. (See grade 8 Language standards 4–6 for additional expectations.)
Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.

Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Read and comprehend complex literary and informational texts independently and proficiently.
meta: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity
College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Analyze how two or more texts address similar themes or topics in order to build knowledge or to compare the approaches the authors take.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, including the validity of the reasoning as well as the relevance and sufficiency of the evidence.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Integrate and evaluate content presented in diverse media and formats, including visually and quantitatively, as well as in words.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Assess how point of view or purpose shapes the content and style of a text.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Analyze the structure of texts, including how specific sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text (e.g., a section, chapter, scene, or stanza) relate to each other and the whole.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Interpret words and phrases as they are used in a text, including determining technical, connotative, and figurative meanings, and analyze how specific word choices shape meaning or tone.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Analyze how and why individuals, events, and ideas develop and interact over the course of a text.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Determine central ideas or themes of a text and analyze their development; summarize the key supporting details and ideas.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Read closely to determine what the text says explicitly and to make logical inferences from it; cite specific textual evidence when writing or speaking to support conclusions drawn from the text.
meta: College and Career Readiness Anchor Standards for Reading

content: Distinguish among the connotations (associations) of words with similar denotations (definitions) (e.g., bullheaded, willful, firm, persistent, resolute).
meta: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

content: Use the relationship between particular words to better understand each of the words.
meta: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

content: Interpret figures of speech (e.g. verbal irony, puns) in context.
meta: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.

content: Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase (e.g., by checking the inferred meaning in context or in a dictionary).
meta: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

content: Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning or its part of speech or trace the etymology of words.
meta: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

content: Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of a word (e.g., precede, recede, secede).
meta: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

content: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word's position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase.
meta: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words or phrases based on grade 8 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.

content: Use verbs in the active and passive voice and in the conditional and subjunctive mood to achieve particular effects (e.g., emphasizing the actor or the action; expressing uncertainty or describing a state contrary to fact).
meta: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

content: Spell correctly.
meta: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

content: Use an ellipsis to indicate an omission.
meta: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

content: Use punctuation (comma, ellipsis, dash) to indicate a pause or break.
meta: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.

content: Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb voice and mood.
meta: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

content: Form and use verbs in the indicative, imperative, interrogative, conditional, and subjunctive mood.
meta: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

content: Form and use verbs in the active and passive voice.
meta: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

content: Explain the function of verbals (gerunds, participles, infinitives) in general and their function in particular sentences.
meta: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.

content: Plan and present a narrative that: establishes a context and point of view, presents a logical sequence, uses narrative techniques (e.g., dialogue, pacing, description, sensory language), uses a variety of transitions, and provides a conclusion that reflects the experience.
meta: Present claims and findings (e.g., argument, narrative, response to literature presentations), emphasizing salient points in a focused, coherent manner with relevant evidence, sound valid reasoning, and well-chosen details; use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation.

content: Acknowledge new information expressed by others, and, when warranted, qualify or justify their own views in light of the evidence presented.
meta: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 8 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly.

content: Pose questions that connect the ideas of several speakers and respond to others' questions and comments with relevant evidence, observations, and ideas.
meta: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 8 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly.

content: Follow rules for collegial discussions and decision-making, track progress toward specific goals and deadlines, and define individual roles as needed.
meta: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 8 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly.

content: Come to discussions prepared, having read or researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence on the topic, text, or issue to probe and reflect on ideas under discussion.
meta: Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 8 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly.

content: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented.
meta: Write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events, scientific procedures/ experiments, or technical processes.

content: Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone.

content: Introduce a topic clearly, previewing what is to follow; organize ideas, concepts, and information into broader categories as appropriate to achieving purpose; include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., charts, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.
meta: Write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events, scientific procedures/ experiments, or technical processes.

content: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from or supports the argument presented.

content: Establish and maintain a formal style.
meta: Write arguments focused on discipline-specific content.

content: Use words, phrases, and clauses to create cohesion and clarify the relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

content: Support claim(s) with logical reasoning and relevant, accurate data and evidence that demonstrate an understanding of the topic or text, using credible sources.

content: Introduce claim(s) about a topic or issue, acknowledge and distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and organize the reasons and evidence logically.

content: Apply grade 8 Reading standards to literary nonfiction (e.g., "Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced").

content: Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on the narrated experiences or events.
meta: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

meta: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

content: Use a variety of transition words, phrases, and clauses to convey sequence, signal shifts from one time frame or setting to another, and show the relationships among experiences and events.
meta: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

content: Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, and reflection, to develop experiences, events, and/or characters.
meta: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, relevant descriptive details, and well-structured event sequences.

content: Engage and orient the reader by establishing a context and point of view and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally and logically.

content: Support claim(s) with logical reasoning and relevant evidence, using accurate, credible sources and demonstrating an understanding of the topic or text.

content: Analyze the use of text features (e.g., graphics, headers, captions) in consumer materials.
